{{Psychology sidebar}} '''Social comparison theory''', initially proposed by [[social psychologist]] [[Leon Festinger]] in 1954,<ref name="Festinger1954">{{cite journal | author = Festinger L | year = 1954 | title = A theory of social comparison processes | url = | journal = Human Relations | volume = 7 | issue = 2| pages = 117–140 | doi=10.1177/001872675400700202}}</ref> centers on the belief that there is a drive within individuals to gain accurate self-evaluations. The theory explains how individuals evaluate their own opinions and abilities by comparing themselves to others in order to reduce uncertainty in these domains, and learn how to define the self.
Following the initial theory, research began to focus on social comparison as a way of self-enhancement,<ref name="Gruder1971">{{cite journal | author = Gruder C. L. | year = 1971 | title = Determinants of social comparison choices | url = | journal = Journal of Experimental Social Psychology | volume = 7 | issue = 5| pages = 473–489 | doi=10.1016/0022-1031(71)90010-2}}</ref><ref name="Wills1981">{{cite journal | author = Wills T. A. | year = 1981 | title = Downward comparison principles in social psychology | url = | journal = Psychological Bulletin | volume = 90 | issue = 2| pages = 245–271 | doi=10.1037/0033-2909.90.2.245}}</ref> introducing the concepts of downward and upward comparisons and expanding the motivations of social comparisons.<ref>Schachter, S. (1959). The psychology of affiliation: Experimental studies of the sources of gregariousness (Vol. 1). Stanford University Press.</ref>
== Initial framework == In the initial theory, Festinger provided nine main hypotheses. First, he stated that humans have a basic drive to evaluate their opinions and abilities and that people evaluate themselves through objective, nonsocial means (Hypothesis I).<ref name="Festinger1954" /> Second, Festinger stated that if objective, nonsocial means were not available, that people evaluate their opinions and abilities by comparison to other people (Hypothesis II).<ref name="Festinger1954" /> Next, he hypothesized that the tendency to compare oneself to another person decreases as the difference between their opinions and abilities becomes more divergent.<ref name="Festinger1954" /> In other words, if someone is much different from you, you are less likely to compare yourself to that person (Hypothesis III). He next hypothesized that there is a unidirectional drive upward in the case of abilities, which is largely absent in opinions.<ref name="Festinger1954" /> This drive refers to the value that is placed on doing better and better.<ref name="Suls, J., Miller, R.">Suls, J., Miller, R. (1977). "Social Comparison Processes: Theoretical and Empirical Perspectives". Hemisphere Publishing Corp., Washington D.C. {{ISBN|0-470-99174-7}}</ref> (Hypothesis IV). Next, Festinger hypothesizes that there are non-social restraints that make it difficult or even impossible to change one's ability and these restraints are largely absent for opinions.<ref name="Festinger1954" /> In other words, people can change their opinions when they want to but no matter how motivated individuals may be to improve their ability, there may be other elements that make this impossible<ref name="Suls, J., Miller, R." /> (Hypothesis V). Festinger goes on to hypothesize that the cessation of comparison with others is accompanied by hostility or derogation to the extent that continued comparison with those persons implies unpleasant consequences (Hypothesis VI). Next, any factors which increase the importance of some particular group as a comparison group from some particular opinion or ability will increase the pressure toward uniformity concerning that ability or opinion within that group. If discrepancies arise between the evaluator and comparison group there is a tendency to reduce the divergence by either attempting to persuade others, or changing their personal views to attain uniformity. However, the importance, relevance and attraction to a comparison group that affects the original motivation for comparison, mediates the pressures towards uniformity (Hypothesis VII). His next hypothesis states that if persons who are very divergent from one's own opinion or ability are perceived as different from oneself on attributes consistent with the divergence, the tendency to narrow the range of comparability becomes stronger (Hypothesis VIII). Lastly, Festinger hypothesized that when there is a range of opinion or ability in a group, the relative strength of the three manifestations of pressures toward uniformity will be different for those who are close to the mode of the group than for those who are distant from the mode. Those close to the mode will have stronger tendencies to change the positions of others, weaker tendencies to narrow the range of comparison, and even weaker tendencies to change their own opinions (Hypothesis IX).<ref name="Festinger1954" />
== Theoretical advances == Since its inception, the initial framework has undergone several advances. Key among these are developments in understanding the motivations that underlie social comparisons, and the particular types of social comparisons that are made. Motives that are relevant to social comparison include self-enhancement,<ref name="Gruder1971" /><ref name="Wills1981" /> maintenance of a positive self-evaluation,<ref name="Tesser1982">{{cite journal | author = Tesser, A. |author2=Campbell, J. | year = 1982 | title = Self-evaluation maintenance and the perception of friends and strangers. | journal = Journal of Personality | volume = 50 | issue = 3 | pages = 261–279 | doi=10.1111/j.1467-6494.1982.tb00750.x}}</ref> components of attributions and validation,<ref name="GoethalsDarley1977">{{cite journal | author = Goethals, G. R. |author2=Darley, J. | year = 1977 | title = Social comparison theory: An attributional approach. | journal = Social Comparison Processes: Theoretical and Empirical Perspectives | pages = 86–109 }}</ref> and the avoidance of closure.<ref name="Sulsetal2002">{{cite journal | author = Suls, J. |author2=Martin, R. |author3=Wheeler, L. | year = 2002 | title = Social comparison: Why, with whom, and with what effect?. | journal = Current Directions in Psychological Science | volume = 11| issue = 5 | pages = 159–163 | doi=10.1111/1467-8721.00191}}</ref><ref name="Kruglanski1990">{{cite journal | author = Kruglanski, A. W. |author2=Mayseless, O. | year = 1990 | title = Classic and current social comparison research: Expanding the perspective. | journal = Psychological Bulletin | volume = 108 | issue = 2 | pages = 195–208 | doi=10.1037/0033-2909.108.2.195|citeseerx=10.1.1.336.1436 }}</ref> While there have been changes in Festinger's original concept, many fundamental aspects remain, including the prevalence of the tendency towards social comparison and the general process that is social comparison.
=== Self-evaluation === According to Thorton and Arrowood, [[self-evaluation]] is one of the functions of social comparison. This is one process that underlies how an individual engages in social comparison.<ref name="Thornton1966">{{cite journal | author = Thorton, D. |author2=Arrowood, A. J. | year = 1966 | title = Self-evaluation, self-enhancement, and the locus of social comparison. | journal = Journal of Experimental Social Psychology | volume = 2 |issue=2 | pages = 591–605 | doi = 10.1016/0022-1031(69)90049-3 }}</ref> Each individual's specific goals will influence how they engage in social comparison. For self-evaluation, people tend to choose a comparison target that is similar to themselves.<ref name="Wood1989">{{cite journal | author = Wood, J. V. | year = 1989 | title = Theory and research concerning social comparisons of personal attributes. | journal = Psychological Bulletin | volume = 106 | issue = 2 | pages = 231–248 | doi=10.1037/0033-2909.106.2.231| citeseerx = 10.1.1.456.7776 }}</ref> Specifically, they are most interested in choosing a target who shares some distinctive characteristic with themselves. Research suggests that most people believe that choosing a similar target helps ensure the accuracy of the self-evaluation.{{citation-needed|date=September 2018}} However, individuals do not always act as unbiased self-evaluators, and accurate self-evaluations may not be the primary goal of social comparison.
=== Self-enhancement === Individuals may also seek self-enhancement, or to improve their self-esteem.<ref name="Wood1989" /> They may interpret, distort, or ignore the information gained by social comparison to see themselves more positively and further their self-enhancement goals. They will also choose to make upward (comparing themselves to someone better off) or downward (comparing themselves to someone worse off) comparisons, depending on which strategy will further their self-enhancement goals. They may also avoid making comparisons period, or avoid making certain types of comparisons. Specifically, when an individual believes that their ability in a specific area is low, they will avoid making upward social comparisons in that area. Unlike for self-evaluation goals, people engaging in social comparison with the goal of self-enhancement may not seek out a target that is similar to themselves. In fact, if a target's similarity is seen as a threat, due to the target outperforming the individual on some dimension, the individual may downplay the similarity of the target to themselves. This notion ties closely to the phenomena in psychology introduced also by Leon Festinger himself as it relates to the diminishing of cognitive dissonance. One does not want to perceive oneself in a way which would downplay one's original belief upon which one's self-esteem is based and therefore in order to reduce the cognitive dissonance, one is willing to change the cognitive representation of the other person whom one compares oneself to, such that one's own belief about oneself remains intact. This effectively leads to the comparison of apples to oranges or psychological denial.
Later advances in theory led to [[self-enhancement]] being one of the four [[self-evaluation motives]]:, along with ''[[self-assessment]]'', ''[[self-verification]]'', and ''[[self-improvement]]''.
{{main|Self-evaluation motives}} {{main|Self-enhancement}} {{main|Self-assessment}} {{main|Self-verification}} {{main|Self-improvement}}
===Upward and downward social comparisons=== Wills introduced the concept of downward comparison in 1981.<ref name="Wills1981" /> Downward social comparison is a defensive tendency that is used as a means of self-evaluation. When a person looks to another individual or group that they consider to be worse off than themselves in order to feel better about their self or personal situation, they are making a downward social comparison. Research has suggested that social comparisons with others who are better off or superior, or upward comparisons, can lower self-regard,<ref name="Tesser1988">{{cite journal | author = Tesser, A. |author2=Millar, M. |author3=Moore, J. | year = 1988 | title = Some affective consequences of social comparison and reflection processes: the pain and pleasure of being close. | journal = Journal of Personality and Social Psychology | volume = 54 | issue = 1 | pages = 49–61 | doi = 10.1037/0022-3514.54.1.49 |pmid=3346807 }}</ref> whereas downward comparisons can elevate self-regard.<ref name="Gibbons1986">{{cite journal | author = Gibbons, F. X.| year = 1986 | title = Social comparison and depression: Company's effect on misery. | journal = Journal of Personality and Social Psychology | volume = 51 | issue = 1 | pages = 140–148 | doi = 10.1037/0022-3514.51.1.140 | pmid = 3735064 }}</ref> Downward comparison theory emphasizes the positive effects of comparisons in increasing one's subjective well-being.<ref name="Wills1981" /> For example, it has been found that breast cancer patients made the majority of comparisons with patients less fortunate than themselves.<ref name="Woodetal1985">{{cite journal | author = Wood, J. V. |author2=Taylor, S. E. |author3=Lichtman, R. R. | year = 1985 | title = Social comparison in adjustment to breast cancer. | journal = Journal of Personality and Social Psychology | volume = 49 | issue = 5 | pages = 1169–1183 | doi = 10.1037/0022-3514.49.5.1169 }}</ref>
Although social comparison research has suggested that upward comparisons can lower self-regard, Collins indicates that this is not always the case.<ref name="Collins1995">{{cite journal | author = Collins, R. L. | year = 1995 | title = For better or worse: The impact of upward social comparison on self-evaluations. | journal = Psychological Bulletin | volume = 119 | issue = 1 | pages = 51–69 | doi = 10.1037/0033-2909.119.1.51 }}</ref> Individuals make upward comparisons, whether consciously or subconsciously, when they compare themselves with an individual or comparison group that they perceive as superior or better than themselves in order to improve their views of self or to create a more positive perception of their personal reality. Upward social comparisons are made to self-evaluate and self-improve in the hopes that self-enhancement will also occur. In an upward social comparison, people want to believe themselves to be part of the elite or superior, and make comparisons highlighting the similarities between themselves and the comparison group, unlike a downward social comparison, where similarities between individuals or groups are disassociated.<ref name="Sulsetal2002" />
It has also been suggested that upward comparisons may provide an inspiration to improve, and in one study it was found that while breast cancer patients made more downward comparisons, they showed a preference for information about more fortunate others.<ref name="Taylor1989">{{cite journal | author = Taylor, S. E. |author2=Lobel, M. | year = 1989 | title = Social comparison activity under threat: Downward evaluation and upward contacts. | journal = Psychological Review | volume = 96 | issue = 4 | pages = 569–575 | doi = 10.1037/0033-295X.96.4.569 | pmid=2678204|citeseerx=10.1.1.318.5713 }}</ref>
Another study indicated that people who were dieting often used upward social comparisons by posting pictures of thinner people on their refrigerators.<ref name="Collins1995" /> These pictures served as not only a reminder of an individuals current weight, but also as an inspiration of a goal to be reached. In simple terms, downward social comparisons are more likely to make us feel better about ourselves, while upward social comparisons are more likely to motivate us to achieve more or reach higher.
===Moderators of social comparison=== Aspinwall and Taylor looked at mood, self-esteem, and threat as moderators that drive individuals to choose to make upward or downward social comparisons.<ref name="Aspinwall1993">{{cite journal | author = Aspinwall, L. G. |author2=Taylor, S. E. | year = 1993 | title = Effects of social comparison direction, threat, and self-esteem on affect, self-evaluation, and expected success. | journal = Journal of Personality and Social Psychology | volume = 64 | issue = 5 | pages = 708–722 | doi = 10.1037/0022-3514.64.5.708 }}</ref> Downward comparisons in cases where individuals had experienced a threat to their self-esteem produced more favorable self-evaluations.
====High self-esteem and social comparison==== Aspinwall and Taylor found that upward social comparisons were good in circumstances where the individuals making the comparisons had high self-esteem, because these types of comparisons provided them with more motivation and hope than downward social comparisons.<ref name="Aspinwall1993" /> However, if these individuals had experienced a recent threat or setback to their self-esteem, they reported that upward comparisons resulted in a more negative affect than downward comparisons.
====Low self-esteem and social comparison==== However, people with low self-esteem or people who are experiencing some sort of threat in their life (such as doing poorly in school, or suffering from an illness) tend to favor downward comparisons over upward comparisons. People with low self-esteem and negative affect improve their mood by making downward comparisons. Their mood does not improve as much as it would if they had high self-esteem. Even for people with low self-esteem, these downward social comparisons do improve their negative mood and allow them to feel hope and motivation for their future.
====Affect/mood and its effect on social comparison==== Individuals who have a negative mood improve their mood by making upward social comparisons, regardless of their level of self-esteem. In addition, both individuals with high self-esteem and low self-esteem who are in a positive mood elevate their mood further by making upward comparisons. However, for those who have recently experienced a threat to their self-esteem or a setback in their life, making upward social comparisons instead of downward social comparisons results in a more negative affect. Self-esteem and existence of a threat or setback in an individual's life are two moderators of their response to upward or downward comparisons.
=== Competitiveness === Because individuals are driven upwards in the case of abilities, social comparisons can drive competition among peers.<ref>Chen, P. & Garcia, S. M. (manuscript) "Yin and Yang Theory of Competition: Social Comparison and Evaluation Apprehension Reciprocally Drive Competitive Motivation". [http://www-personal.umich.edu/~prestos/Downloads/DC/ChenGarciasubmitted.doc link].</ref> In this regard, the psychological significance of a comparison depends on the social status of an individual, and the context in which their abilities are being evaluated.
==== Social status ==== Competitiveness resulting from social comparisons may be greater in relation to higher social status because individuals with more status have more to lose. In one study, students in a classroom were presented with a bonus point program where, based on chance, the grades for some students would increase and the grades for others would remain the same. Despite the fact that students could not lose by this program, higher-status individuals were more likely to object to the program, and more likely to report a perceived [[distributive justice|distributive injustice]]. It was suggested that this was a cognitive manifestation of an aversion to [[social mobility|downward mobility]], which has more psychological significance when an individual has more status.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Burleigh T. J. |author2=Meegan D. V. | year = 2013 | title = Keeping up with the Joneses affects perceptions of distributive justice | url = https://www.researchgate.net/publication/236111382 | format = PDF | journal = Social Justice Research | volume = 26| issue = 2| pages = 120–131| doi = 10.1007/s11211-013-0181-3 |citeseerx=10.1.1.693.335 }}</ref>
==== Proximity to a standard ==== When individuals are evaluated where meaningful standards exist, such as in an academic classroom where students are ranked, then competitiveness increases as proximity to a standard of performance increases. When the only meaningful standard is the top, then high-ranking individuals are most competitive with their peers, and individuals at low and intermediate ranks are equally competitive. However, when both high and low rankings hold significance, then individuals at high and low ranks are equally competitive, and are both more competitive than individuals at intermediate ranks.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Garcia S. M. |author2=Tor A. | year = 2007 | title = Rankings, standards, and competition: Task vs. scale comparisons | url = | journal = Organizational Behavior and Human Decision Processes | volume = 102 | issue = 1| pages = 95–108 | doi = 10.1016/j.obhdp.2006.10.004 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author1=Garcia S. M. |author2=Tor A. |author3=Gonzalez R. | year = 2006 | title = Ranks and rivals: a theory of competition | url = http://scholarship.law.nd.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1715&context=law_faculty_scholarship| journal = Personality & Social Psychology Bulletin | volume = 32 | issue = 7| pages = 970–82 | doi = 10.1177/0146167206287640 |pmid=16738029 }}</ref>
=== Models of social comparison === Several models have been introduced to social comparison, including the [[self-evaluation maintenance model]] (SEM),<ref name="Tesser1988" /> [[proxy model]],<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Wheeler L. |author2=Martin R. |author3=Suls J. | year = 1997 | title = The proxy model of social comparison for self-assessment of ability | url = | journal = Personality and Social Psychology Review | volume = 1 | issue = 1| pages = 54–61 | doi=10.1207/s15327957pspr0101_4|pmid=15647128 }}</ref> the [[triadic model]] and the [[three-selves model]].<ref name="Blanton2001">Blanton, H. (2001). Evaluating the self in the context of another: The three-selves model of social comparison assimilation and contrast. In Cognitive social psychology: The Princeton symposium on the legacy and future of social cognition (pp. 75-87). Mahwah, NJ: Erlbaum.</ref>
==== Self-evaluation maintenance model ==== The SEM model proposes that we make comparisons to maintain or enhance our self-evaluations, focusing on the antagonistic processes of comparison and reflection.<ref name="Tesser1988" /> Abraham Tesser has conducted research on self-evaluation dynamics that has taken several forms. A self-evaluation maintenance (SEM) model of social behavior focuses on the consequences of another person's outstanding performance on one's own self-evaluation. It sketches out some conditions under which the other's good performance bolsters self-evaluation, i.e., "basking in reflected glory", and conditions under which it threatens self-evaluation through a comparison process.<ref name="Tesser Website">Tesser, A., Social Psychology Network; http://tesser.socialpsychology.org/</ref>
==== Proxy model ==== The proxy model anticipates the success of something that is unfamiliar. The model proposes that if a person is successful or familiar with a task, then he or she would also be successful at a new similar task. The proxy is evaluated based on ability and is concerned with the question "Can I do X?" A proxy's comparison is based previous attributes. The opinion of the comparer and whether the proxy exerted maximum effort on a preliminary task are variables influencing his or her opinion.<ref name="Sulsetal2002" />
==== Triadic model ==== The Triadic Model builds on the attribution elements of social comparison, proposing that opinions of social comparison are best considered in terms of 3 different evaluative questions: preference assessment (i.e., "Do I like X?"), belief assessment (i.e., "Is X correct?"), and preference prediction (i.e., "Will I like X?"). In the Triadic Model the most meaningful comparisons are with a person who has already experienced a proxy and exhibits consistency in related attributes or past preferences.<ref name="Sulsetal2002" />
==== Three-selves model ==== The three-selves model proposes that social comparison theory is a combination of two different theories. One theory is developed around motivation and the factors that influence the type of social comparison information people seek from their environment and the second is about self-evaluation and the factors that influence the effects of social comparisons on the judgments of self.<ref name="Blanton2001" /> While there has been much research in the area of comparison motives, there has been little in the area of comparative evaluation. Explaining that the self is conceived as interrelated conceptions accessible depending upon current judgment context<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Markus H. |author2=Wurf E. | year = 1987 | title = The dynamic self-concept: A social psychological perspective | url = | journal = Annual Review of Psychology | volume = 38 | issue = 1| pages = 299–337 | doi=10.1146/annurev.psych.38.1.299}}</ref> and taking a cue from [[Social Cognitive Theory]], this model examines the [[Assimilation effect]] and distinguishes three classes of working [[Self-concept]] ideas: individual selves, possible selves and collective selves.
== Media influence == The media has been found to play a large role in social comparisons. Researchers examining the social effects of the media have used social comparison theory have found that in most cases women tend to engage in upward social comparisons with a target other, which results in more negative feelings about the self. The majority of women have a daily opportunity to make upward comparison by measuring themselves against some form of societal ideal. Social comparisons have become a relevant mechanism for learning about the appearance-related social expectations among peers and for evaluating the self in terms of those standards" (Jones, 2001, P. 647).
Although men do make upward comparisons, research finds that more women make upward comparisons and are comparing themselves with unrealistically high standards presented in the media.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Strahan E. J. |author2=Wilson A. E. |author3=Cressman K. E. |author4=Buote V. M. | year = 2006 | title = Comparing to perfection: How cultural norms for appearance affect social comparisons and self-image | url = | journal = Body Image | volume = 3 | issue = 3| pages = 211–227 | doi=10.1016/j.bodyim.2006.07.004|pmid=18089224 }}</ref> As women are shown more mainstream media images of powerful, successful and thin women, they perceive the "ideal" to be the norm for societal views of attractive. In recent years, social media platforms such as Facebook and Instagram have made this more widespread, since social media makes it easier to compare yourself to the "ideal". Some women have reported making upward comparisons in a positive manner for the purposes of self-motivation, but the majority of upward comparisons are made when the individual is feeling lesser and therefore evoke a negative connotation.
Self-perceived similarities with role models on social media can also affect self-esteem for both men and women. Having more self-perceived similarities with a role model can help increase self-esteem, while having less can decrease self-esteem.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wohlford|first=Kathryn E.|last2=Lochman|first2=John E.|last3=Barry|first3=Tammy D.|date=2004-04-01|title=The Relation Between Chosen Role Models and the Self-Esteem of Men and Women|journal=Sex Roles|language=en|volume=50|issue=7–8|pages=575–582|doi=10.1023/B:SERS.0000023076.54504.ca|issn=0360-0025}}</ref>Social comparison with peers on social media can also lead to feelings of self-pity or satisfaction. The desire for social comparison can cause [[Fear of missing out|FoMO]] and compulsive checking of social media sites.
== Criticisms == Many criticisms arose regarding Festinger's similarity hypothesis. Deutsch and Krauss<ref>Deutsch, M., & Krauss, R. M. (1965). Theories in social psychology (Vol. 2). New York: Basic Books.</ref> argued that people actually seek out dissimilar others in their comparisons maintaining that this is important for providing valuable self-knowledge, as demonstrated in research.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Goethals G. R. |author2=Nelson R. E. | year = 1973 | title = Similarity in the influence process: The belief-value distinction | url = | journal = Journal of Personality and Social Psychology | volume = 25 | issue = 1| pages = 117–122 | doi=10.1037/h0034266}}</ref><ref>Mettee, D. R., & Smith, G. (1977). Social comparison and interpersonal attraction: The case for dissimilarity. Social comparison processes: Theoretical and empirical perspectives, 69, 101.</ref> Ambiguity also circulated about the important dimensions for similarity. Goethals and Darley clarified the role of similarity suggesting that people prefer to compare those who are similar on related attributes such as opinions, characteristics or abilities to increase confidence for value judgments, however those dissimilar in related attributes are preferred when validating one's beliefs.<ref name="GoethalsDarley1977" />

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} [[File:Britney Europe.jpg|thumb|Rise in popularity of thongs among younger girls has been attributed to pop idols like [[Britney Spears]] and [[Jennifer Lopez]].<ref name="auto">[http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/chronicle/archive/2002/06/16/LV184497.DTL Grin and bare it], San Francisco Chronicles</ref> Picture shows Britney Spears performing, 2011.]] The '''social impact of thong underwear''' has been covered extensively in the media, ranging from a ban on wearing [[thong (clothing)|thong]]s to thongs for the underaged. The rise of thong usage has been asserted by Christian minister Oneil McQuick to be linked to a rise of [[sexualization]] in society,<ref>{{cite book|first=Oneil|last=McQuick|url=https://books.google.com/?id=Ewm93pO7YQcC&pg=PT1&dq=thong+society+sex|title=The Sexuality Series|page=29|publisher=L.I.M Publishing|year=2007|isbn=1-4196-4225-1}}</ref> and by Christian writer Philo Thelos to be linked to a rise in a desire to go unclothed.<ref>{{cite book|first=Philo|last=Thelos|url=https://books.google.com/?id=KpYJYeKiss8C&pg=PA52&dq=thong+society+sex|title=Divine Sex: Liberating Sex from Religious Tradition|page=52|publisher=Trafford Publishing|year=2003|isbn=1-55395-400-9}}</ref>
== Overview == [[File:Thong (cropped).jpg|thumb|Woman wearing a T-back thong in [[Sunrise, Florida]], USA in 2006]]
When discussing the trend of wearing thongs, Christian writer Sharon Daugherty comments in her book ''What Guys See That Girls Don't: Or Do They?'' that the fashion industry "may have changed the mindset of our society",<ref>{{cite book|first=Sharon|last=Daugherty|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=g3kx5Z42GPYC||title=What Guys See That Girls Don't: Or Do They?|page=61|publisher=Destiny Image Publishers|year=2006|isbn=0-7684-2368-6}}</ref> which was followed by the observation that "the whole idea of wearing so that no panty line or bumps can show isn't substantiated" and that "the thong was created by fashion designers to arouse sexual thoughts".{{sfn|Daugherty|2006|page=63}}
[[Monica Lewinsky]] gave evidence during the [[Lewinsky scandal]] that she was flirting with [[Bill Clinton]] in [[Leon Panetta]]'s office, and that she lifted her jacket to show him the straps of her thong underwear above her pants.<ref>{{cite web | last = Starr | first = Kenneth | author-link = Ken Starr | title = Report to the House on President Clinton: Narrative Pt. II: Initial Sexual Encounters (extract) | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/politics/special/clinton/icreport/6narritii.htm | website = washingtonpost.com | publisher = [[The Washington Post]] | date = September 1998 }}</ref> Some of the news media in America used thong underwear as a metonym for smut in the [[Starr Report]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/explainer/1998/09/the_thong_show.html|title=The Thong Show|date=22 September 1998|publisher=|via=Slate}}</ref> According to feminist commentator [[Carrie Lukas]], Lewinsky "with her thong-snapping seduction, forever changed the image of the D.C. junior staffer from aspiring policy wonk to sexual temptress."<ref>{{citation | last = Lukas | first = Carrie | author-link = Carrie Lukas | contribution = Sex: love's got something to do with it | editor-last = Lukas | editor-first = Carrie | editor-link = Carrie Lukas | title = The politically incorrect guide to women, sex, and feminism | page = 21 | publisher = Regency Publishing | location = Washington, DC Lanham, Maryland | year = 2006 | isbn = 9781596980037 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} [https://books.google.com/books?id=BVf_dCr023IC&pg=PA21&dq=thong+woman+sex&lr=&ei=sw4FSOahHIT6yATl3pj-Dw&sig=OCS8-3Pm9Npbe4q3ZRklqehUVzE#PPA21,M1 Preview.]</ref>
Marketing analysts Marian L. Salzman, Ira Matathia and Ann O'Reilly observed in the book ''Buzz: Harness the Power of Influence and Create Demand'' that thong brands are riding on the wide media coverage of thongs to create [[Word of mouth|buzz]].<ref>Marian L. Salzman, Ira Matathia and Ann O'Reilly, [https://books.google.com/books?id=sf85DYe9140C&pg=PA116&dq=thong+society+sex&lr=&ei=4vcESNDMF5jWyATNt_D9Dg&sig=f7ebSu-0y8UlAac7H8tqhsOIUiw Buzz: Harness the Power of Influence and Create Demand], Page 116, John Wiley and Sons, 2003, {{ISBN|0-471-27345-7}}</ref> Photographer [[Lauren Greenfield]] wrote in her book ''Girl Culture'', "Understanding the [[dialectic]] between the extreme and the mainstream – the anorexic and the dieter, the stripper and the teenager who bares her midriff or wears a thong – is essential to understanding contemporary feminine identity."<ref>Lauren Greenfield, [https://books.google.com/books?id=TUT9vKPr4_YC&pg=PT155&dq=thong+britney+spears&lr=&ei=TxEFSNTxLYOOywSSjuCiDw&sig=gCRLKGJiBIpHS_FdG9K02x9uk4k Girl Culture], Chronicle Books, 2002, {{ISBN|0-8118-3790-4}}</ref>
In 2004, political commentator Cedric Muhammad wrote in essay ''The Thong versus the Veil'', "We wondered at the end of the day, of the two groups of women most prominently featured on American TV these days, who gains more respect for their intellect and spirit – the Afghan woman who is so totally veiled that you can't even see her eyes or the Black woman in the R&B and Hip-Hop video who dances while wearing a bikini and thong?"<ref>Laura Flanders (ed.), [https://books.google.com/books?id=gg5NNztsUooC&pg=PA180&dq=thong+culutre+sex&lr=&ei=DhgFSLXXPJTAzATBy_yXDg&sig=QZNRmkA0_poI66Hywqj9tkkPYyg#PPA181,M1 The W Effect: Bush's War on Women], Page 181, Feminist Press, 2004, {{ISBN|1-55861-471-0}}</ref>
==School restrictions== The dress code for [[St. Ambrose Academy]], a Roman Catholic middle school and high school in [[Madison, Wisconsin]], specifically addresses swimsuits with "thong-cut legs" as inappropriate.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ambroseacademy.org/dresscode.pdf |title=Ambrose Academy website |publisher=Ambroseacademy.org |accessdate=1 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080727005219/http://www.ambroseacademy.org/dresscode.pdf |archivedate=27 July 2008 |df=dmy }}</ref> At [[Dixon High School (California)|Dixon High School]] in [[Dixon, California]], the dress code specifies that all undergarments – specifically listing thongs, along with [[bra]]s and [[briefs]] – must be covered.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dhs.dixonusd.org/PAGES/Information/rules_dress.htm |title=Dixon High School |publisher=Dhs.dixonusd.org |date= |accessdate=2013-03-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011210154/http://dhs.dixonusd.org/PAGES/Information/rules_dress.htm |archivedate=11 October 2007 |df=dmy }}</ref> [[University of Victoria]] Law School briefly put the school logo on thongs, but quickly pulled them from sale after controversy sprung up.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indissent.com/jan2003/lawnews.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030810135944/http://www.indissent.com/jan2003/lawnews.htm |archivedate=2003-08-10 |title=Indissent, University of Victoria |publisher=Web.archive.org |date=10 August 2003 |accessdate=1 January 2012}}</ref>
In 1999 a [[Miami University]] male professor was banned from using the school's recreation center because he refused to stop wearing thong swimwear. The professor challenged the school in court.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://enquirer.com/editions/1999/03/02/loc_professor_sues_miami.html|title= Professor sues Miami U to keep thong swimsuit |date=2 March 1999|accessdate=6 January 2016|publisher=[[Cincinnati Enquirer]]}}</ref> In 2000 a [[Salinas, California|Salinas]] High School principal was in the center of a variety of controversies including bans on clothing to the extent that "thong panties were unofficially banned." One student alleged that she was given a dress-code violation note for wearing a thong.<ref name="Monterey County Weekly" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metroactive.com/papers/metro/12.14.00/dresscode-0050.html |title=Metro Active |publisher=Metro Active |date=14 September 2000 |accessdate=1 January 2012}}</ref> This story made national headlines in the United States.<ref name="Monterey County Weekly">[https://archive.is/20070628153120/http://www.montereycountyweekly.com/articles/7128/print Monterey County Weekly] </ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0009/13/tod.04.html |title=CNN transcript |publisher=Transcripts.cnn.com |date=13 September 2000 |accessdate=1 January 2012}}</ref>
In 2002, a female high school vice principal in San Diego physically checked up to 100 female students' underwear<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.10news.com/news/1515763/detail.html |title=Channel 10 news |publisher=10news.com |date=17 June 2002 |accessdate=1 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111120184346/http://www.10news.com/news/1515763/detail.html |archivedate=20 November 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref> as they entered the school for a dance, with or without student permission, causing an uproar among students and some parents and eliciting an investigation by the school into the vice principal's conduct.<ref>[http://www.nbcsandiego.com/News/1427309/detail.html NBC San Diego] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011160853/http://www.nbcsandiego.com/News/1427309/detail.html |date=11 October 2007 }}</ref> In her defense, the vice principal said the checks were for student safety and not specifically because of the wearing of thongs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/northcounty/20020605-9999_2m5thong.html |title=> News > North County - 2 on RB High staff faulted for checks of undergarments |publisher=SignOnSanDiego.com |date=2002-06-05 |accessdate=2013-03-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/northcounty/20020616-9999_2m16thong.html |title=> News > North County - Demotion possible for assistant principal |publisher=SignOnSanDiego.com |date=2002-06-16 |accessdate=2013-03-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/2002/06/18/thong-demotion.htm |title=USA Today |work=USA Today |date=18 June 2002 |accessdate=1 January 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2002/06/18/national/main512654.shtml |title=CBS News |publisher=CBS News |date=11 February 2009 |accessdate=1 January 2012}}</ref><ref>[http://www.nbcsandiego.com/News/1429777/detail.html NBC San Diego] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071214172315/http://www.nbcsandiego.com/News/1429777/detail.html |date=14 December 2007 }}</ref> In 2003, the [[head teacher]] of a British primary school voiced her concern after learning that female students as young as 10 were wearing thong underwear to school. This incident led to a media debate about the appropriateness of thong underwear marketed to young girls.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/education/2943874.stm |title=Bbc (Uk) |publisher=BBC News |date=28 May 2003 |accessdate=1 January 2012}}</ref>
==Sports== The [[University of California]] [[4-H]] program specifically forbids "string, thong or crochet" swimsuits for women.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ucce.ucdavis.edu/files/filelibrary/2557/28364.doc |title=University of California, Davis |accessdate=1 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120208005132/http://ucce.ucdavis.edu/files/filelibrary/2557/28364.doc |archivedate=8 February 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref> For men, the dress code specifies "swim trunks only (no shorts, cut-off pants, or Speedos)." A similar policy by [[Virginia]] [[FCCLA]] bans "skimpy bikini or thong type suits" for women and specifies "swim trunks" for men ("no speedos").<ref>[http://www.me.vccs.edu/fccla/documents/DressCode_000.doc VCCS FCCLA website]{{dead link|date=January 2012}}</ref>
In 2001, [[Vicky Botwright]], then 16th seeded in women's squash circuit and dubbed the "Lancashire Hot Bot", was prohibited by the [[Women's International Squash Players Association]] (WISPA) from wearing a thong and a sports bra in the British Open Championships.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/low/other_sports/1408489.stm |title=All thong wrong @ BBC Sports Online |accessdate= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20021203211540/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/low/other_sports/1408489.stm |archivedate=3 December 2002 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
In 2004, Alexander Putnam competed in the [[London Marathon]] in a green thong and painted as a tropical tree to protest against logging in Congo.<ref>[http://www.rainforestfoundationuk.org/s-%93Mara-thong%94%20Man%20runs%20from%20Congo%20loggers "Mara-thong" Man runs from Congo loggers], Rainforest Foundation</ref>
[[Female bodybuilder]]s in America are prohibited from wearing thong or T-back swimsuits if contests are being filmed for television, otherwise they are allowed to do so by certain fitness organizations.<ref>Maria R. Lowe, ''Women of steel: female bodybuilders and the struggle for self-definition'', page 191, New York University Press, 1998, {{ISBN|0-8147-5094-X}}</ref>
==Bans== In October 2002, Florida officials banned thongs from [[Daytona Beach, Florida|Daytona Beach]] and other public beaches.<ref>{{cite newspaper|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/2003-01-05-spring-break-usat_x.htm|title=Alcohol-soaked spring break lures students abroad|newspaper=USA Today|author=Donna Leinwand|date=2003-01-05}}</ref>
==Thongs for younger girls== The 2000s saw a rise in the popularity of thongs among younger girls, who have been dubbed "thong feminists" by comedian [[Janeane Garofalo]]. The trend has been attributed to pop idols like [[Britney Spears]] and [[Jennifer Lopez]].<ref name="auto"/> In 2002 [[Abercrombie & Fitch]] released a line of thong underwear targeted for girls ages 10–16, though critics pointed out that children as young as seven could fit one of the thongs.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/2002/05/22/news/companies/abercrombie/ |title=CNN Money |publisher=CNN |date=28 May 2002 |accessdate=1 January 2012}}</ref><ref name="JS Online">[http://www.jsonline.com/story/index.aspx?id=43941 JS Online] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071114063620/http://www.jsonline.com/story/index.aspx?id=43941 |date=14 November 2007 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E0DE3D9163BF937A15756C0A9649C8B63 |title=New York Times |work=New York Times |date=24 May 2002 |accessdate=1 January 2012 |first=Leslie |last=Kaufman}}</ref> A spokesman for A&F, Hampton Carney, stated that he could list "at least 100 reasons why a young girl would want thong underwear."<ref name="JS Online"/> This controversy spawned a great deal of free publicity for Abercrombie, including a chain letter that received wide circulation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.breakthechain.org/exclusives/aandf.html |title=Break the Chain website |publisher=Breakthechain.org |date=6 June 2002 |accessdate=1 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120122041435/http://www.breakthechain.org/exclusives/aandf.html |archivedate=22 January 2012 }}</ref> British retailer [[Argos (retailer)|Argos]] produced child-size thongs and padded [[Brassiere|bras]] for girls as young as nine, eliciting a similar response from the public.<ref>{{cite news|author=20 Feb 2007 |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2007/02/20/ngirls220.xml |title=(UK) |publisher=The Telegraph |date=20 February 2007 |accessdate=1 January 2012 |location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=This Is Money |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/pages/live/articles/news/news.html?in_article_id=363110&in_page_id=1770&in_a_source=&ito=1490 |title=(UK) |work=Daily Mail |location=UK |date=9 July 2001 |accessdate=1 January 2012}}</ref> [[Etam UK|Etam]], another British retailer, produced [[Sheer (textile)|sheer]] [[Top (clothing)|top]]s and thong underwear for girls of similar age.<ref>[http://www.thesun.co.uk/article/0,,2-2003140951,00.html The Sun (UK)]{{dead link|date=January 2012}}</ref> In Japan, photobooks and DVDs of underaged girls in T-back thongs has become popular as "T-back Junior Idols", which has come under scorn as a new form of child pornography.<ref>[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20070503f1.html Photos of preteen girls in thongs now big business], Japan Times</ref>
==Indecent exposure== * In August 2007 a man in Texas was arrested for [[indecent exposure]] for being naked in his own backyard. He reported that he was in fact wearing a thong and was not naked.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sanmarcosrecord.com/local/local_story_220113341.html |title=San Marcos Daily Record "Backyard exposure leads to arrest" |publisher=Sanmarcosrecord.com |date=8 August 2007 |accessdate=1 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090907090215/http://www.sanmarcosrecord.com/local/local_story_220113341.html |archivedate=7 September 2009 |df=dmy }}</ref>
==Other impacts== * A [[YMCA]] management firm has addressed thongs in dress code policy, stating (in different areas) that "thong-type wear isn't an issue." Additionally, an email from a university fitness center implied that there are safety issues ("thongs on bike seats") that would need to be addressed.<ref name="Monterey County Weekly"/> * In 2007 a man who had broken into a home wearing only a thong was sentenced to 20 years in prison for burglary and attempted rape.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wcpo.com/news/local/story.aspx?content_id=c8cbbd15-6323-407c-a4c6-ce127acc23b3|title=WPCO 9 (ABC) "Thong-Wearing Burglar Sentenced"|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071215025154/http://www.wcpo.com/news/local/story.aspx?content_id=c8cbbd15-6323-407c-a4c6-ce127acc23b3|archivedate=15 December 2007|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.local12.com/news/local/story.aspx?content_id=310a577e-96c7-48fe-ba8c-6e3d857308c6 |title=WKRC 12 (CW) "Thong Robber Sentenced to Prison Time" |publisher=Local12.com |date=24 July 2007 |accessdate=1 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080518091250/http://www.local12.com/news/local/story.aspx?content_id=310a577e-96c7-48fe-ba8c-6e3d857308c6 |archivedate=18 May 2008 |df=dmy }}</ref> He pleaded "guilty but mentally ill" at the May trial and was sentenced in July. * In 2007 the [[Tennessee]] Department of Correction banned prison visitors from wearing thong or g-string underwear. In the words of Correction Commissioner George Little, prisoners "don't need any help getting turned on."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,290945,00.html |title=Fox News "Tennessee Bans Prison Visitors From Wearing G-Strings, Sexy Lingerie" |publisher=Fox News |accessdate=1 January 2012 |date=7 December 2011}}</ref> * After the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake|2004 Indian Ocean tsunami]], thousands of thongs were donated to relief organizations sending relief packages to [[Sri Lanka]]. These were largely discarded amongst the influx of more culturally sensitive and functional utilitarian clothing items. * During photography for [[Google Street View]], a woman in a thong was one of the images discovered that caused consternation over the project.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.seoreligion.com/google-street-view-showing-sunbathing-and-a-womans-thong.html |title=» Google Street View Showing Sunbathing and A Woman’s Thong » Blog Archive » SEO/SEM News |publisher=News.seoreligion.com |date=3 June 2007 |accessdate=1 January 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111220070543/http://news.seoreligion.com/google-street-view-showing-sunbathing-and-a-womans-thong.html |archive-date=20 December 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> * In 2005, the [[Daily News (New York)|New York Daily News]] reported an incident of female United States military soldiers in Iraq stripping down to their thongs to participate in [[mud wrestling]] as an entertaining show.<ref>[http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/news/2005/02/06/2005-02-06_out_of_control_at_camp_crazy.html Female soldiers dress down & get dirty for mud romps G.I.S GONE WILD], NY Daily News {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080519003450/http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/news/2005/02/06/2005-02-06_out_of_control_at_camp_crazy.html |date=19 May 2008 }}</ref>
==Popular culture==
* In 2000, [[R&B]] singer [[Sisqó]] recorded the "[[Thong Song]]" on his ''[[Unleash the Dragon]]'' album. * Writer-director Glen Weiss made three movies titled the ''[[Thong Girl]]'', based on the comic book of the same name.<ref>{{cite web|author=Lloyd DeBerry |url=http://www.thonggirlfilms.com/ |title=Thong Girl |publisher=Thonggirlfilms.com |accessdate=1 January 2012}}</ref> The story of the films revolved around the Thong Girl, an independent [[superhero]]. Parts of the film were shot in [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]]'s mayor's office in 2007.<ref>[http://www.indissent.com/jan2003/lawnews.htm In Dissent] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011172530/http://www.indissent.com/jan2003/lawnews.htm |date=11 October 2007 }}</ref> * Beermaker [[Rolling Rock]] aired a commercial poking fun of male thong wearers during [[Super Bowl|Super Bowl XLI]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.splendad.com/ads/show/443-Rolling-Rock-Man-Thong-Apology |title=SplendAD |publisher=SplendAD |accessdate=1 January 2012}}</ref> * [[Shefali Zariwala]], a model in [[India]], became known as the "thong girl" for her performance in the music video of the song ''Kaanta Laga''.<ref>[http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/bangalore-times/im-indias-original-thong-girl/articleshow/1874777.cms 'I'm India's original thong girl'], Times of India</ref> The album sold two million copies and the music video became an overnight success in India.<ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/worldtoday/content/2003/s1013035.htm Indian Government censors music videos], Australian Broadcasting Corporation</ref> * In 2008, a diamond studded thong worth US$122,000 was featured in a Singapore lingerie fashion show. It had 518 brilliant-cut diamonds, totaling {{convert|30|carat|g}}, studded into the front of a black lace thong in a floral pattern, as well as 27 white gold tassels hanging off it.<ref>[http://in.reuters.com/article/oddlyEnoughNews/idINSIN13091520080403 Diamond thong shown to the throng] Reuters</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Fashion|Sociology}} *[[Thong (clothing)]] *[[G-string]] *[[Whale tail]] *[[Sexual objectification]] *[[Sexual revolution]] *[[Underwear as outerwear]]
